TITLE: Ben Bernanke Among Nobel Economics Prize Winners
SUMMARY: The other two winners were Douglas Diamond and Philip H. Dybvig, whose work helped governments and central bankers navigate the global financial crisis and avoid a 1930s-style depression.

TITLE: World's Emergency-Lending Capacity Is Getting Stretched
SUMMARY: The IMF and World Bank ramped up their lending in the past two years as the world’s crises deepened. Now, poor countries are being hammered by inflation and the Fed’s rate rises.

TITLE: Economy Week Ahead: Inflation and Retail Sales in Focus
SUMMARY: New data will provide details on whether high inflation eased or accelerated.

TITLE: Strong Dollar Pressures U.S. Manufacturing Rebound
SUMMARY: The dollar’s broad-based surge is handing foreign producers an advantage in selling into the U.S., while U.S.-made goods become more expensive for foreign buyers.

TITLE: Burger King's New U.S. CEO Seeks to Restore Chain's Luster
SUMMARY: Parent company Restaurant Brands has installed new leadership and earmarked $400 million to boost advertising and revamp everything from restaurant design to the way its flagship burgers are constructed.

TITLE: Not Ready for Full EV? Some Car Makers Bet Big on Hybrids
SUMMARY: Auto buyers’ appetite for battery-powered vehicles is helping elevate demand for their evolutionary predecessor, the gas-electric vehicle.

TITLE: Electric-Vehicle Makers and Suppliers Drive Into a Stormy IPO Market
SUMMARY: Electric-vehicle makers in Asia and the companies that supply them are rushing to capital markets to raise money, as they try to take advantage of a surge in demand for energy-efficient automobiles.

TITLE: BAE, U.S. in Talks to Restart M777 Howitzer Production After Ukraine Success
SUMMARY: The potential resurrection of the big gun shows how the war in Ukraine could reshape the global arms industry.

TITLE: As Europe Caps Energy Bills, Merits of Price Controls Get Another Look
SUMMARY: Economists say price controls typically increase demand and suppress supply, leading to shortages. Still, many EU countries are capping energy prices, renewing debate on the measures.

TITLE: Fed's Inflation Fight Has Some Economists Fearing an Unnecessarily Deep Downturn
SUMMARY: Rapid rate increases provide less time for central bankers to study their economic effects.

TITLE: More Businesses Want to Hire People With Criminal Records Amid Tight Job Market
SUMMARY: Companies including banks, pharmacy chains and railroads have recognized so-called second-chance hiring can help them find more workers.

TITLE: CEO of Biotech Lobbying Group on Leave Amid Clash Over Direction
SUMMARY: Dr. Michelle McMurry-Heath is on leave amid dissent within BIO, the industry’s top Washington lobbying group, about its direction and concern about its results, according to people familiar with the group.

TITLE: You Hated Your Cable Package. Your Streaming Services Are Bringing It Back.
SUMMARY: From Amazon to HBO Max, entertainment companies are exploring discounted packages and partnerships with rivals; “the great rebundling.”

TITLE: Rivian Recalls Nearly All of Its Vehicles Due to Loose Fastener
SUMMARY: Auto maker says an improperly installed fastener could cause excess wheel tilt and a potential loss of steering control.

TITLE: Israel's Defense Industry Is Big Winner After Abraham Accords
SUMMARY: No one has benefited more from warming diplomatic relations within the Middle East than Israel’s military contractors.

TITLE: Elon Musk's Monster Week of Juggling Twitter, Tesla and SpaceX
SUMMARY: The world’s richest man saw his rocket company ferry astronauts to space, his car company disappoint Wall Street, and he once again offered to buy one of his favorite messaging tools.

TITLE: U.S. Curbs Chip Exports in Bid to Slow China's Military Advance
SUMMARY: Under the new rules, chip manufacturers must obtain a license from the Commerce Department to export advanced semiconductors and chip-making equipment.

TITLE: How the Head of Arby's and Dunkin' Learned to Care About Company Culture
SUMMARY: Inspire Brands CEO Paul Brown says his time at Hilton taught him that brand identity trumps an operating manual.
